repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - State Highway Management Project -
            Sao Paulo

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the State Highway Management Project, Sao
            Paulo (Brazil). The project was successful in achieving its
            physical objectives, but less so in achieving its
            institutional goals. The project fell short of achieving two
            of its objectives: (i) enforcement of axle-load regulations,
            which was ineffective as controls were carried out only
            sporadically, and (ii) appropriately funding highway
            expenditures, which was not periodically reviewed to ensure
            compliance with sound economic policies and criteria. The
            main lessons drawn from the project are: 1) the importance
            of predicting financial difficulties due to macro-economic
            instability, high inflation and poor sector performance.
            Project designers should assess financial risks to the same
            degree as any other project risk and take them into account
            in defining project scope and implementation schedules; 2)
            the importance of avoiding an excessive number of studies
            and/or overwhelming technical assistance, taking into
            consideration government commitment to reform, absorptive
            capacity of the executing agency, as well as the limited
            capacity and resources of the Bank to effectively supervise
            the technical assistance components; such aspects should be
            considered explicitly up front; 3) the importance of
            continuity, both of government and Bank staff in charge of
            the project; in this particular case, their absence bears a
            share of the responsibility for the difficulties experienced
            by the project; 4) the importance of relating the frequency
            of supervision missions to the difficulties developed by the
            project, rather than to a predetermined standard; and 5)
            axle-load control: on strong pavements and good road
            condition, enforcement of axle load regulations using
            obsolete technology (static and manually-operated weighing
            stations) may not be an appropriate policy.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Sao Paulo State Highways
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The State Highway Management Project -
            Sao Paulo seeks to assist the Roads Department in Sao Paulo
            State (DER-SP) in the implementation of selected components
            of its 1987-1990 expenditure program and, through supporting
            institutional reforms, aims to help improve the efficiency
            of administration to achieve more effective management of
            the State transport system.  To that end, the proposed
            project comprises:  (i) civil works for the rehabilitation
            and periodic maintenance of State highways and associated
            consultant services for engineering design and construction
            supervision; (ii) equipment rehabilitation; (iii) a training
            program; and (iv) technical assistance for studies related
            to State transport policy, planning and operations, and
            highway management and research. Quantifiable project
            benefits will accrue to the economy at large, through
            vehicle operating costs savings.  In addition, intensified
            staff training and other institutional measures supported by
            the technical assistance are expected to improve the overall
            efficiency of the management and operations of the State
            transport sector and, in particular, the highway subsector.
